submissions.description: Car maintenance tracking, recording and reminders
submissions.team_members: David Ihim, Justin Tinker, Oluseyi Olujide

submissions.description: Nexus is a decentralized blockchain interoperability protocol designed for arbitrary cross-chain messaging
submissions.team_members: Daniel Marin

submissions.description: Implementing an NFT minter on the Chia blockchain.
submissions.team_members: Jennifer He, Ende Shen, Aaron Reed, Finn Dayton

submissions.project_name: Nouns DAO and Challenges in its Governance Protocol
submissions.team_members: Winnie Xiao

submissions.description: Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) are a hot topic on the internet, with use cases ranging from media collectibles to Proof-of-Attendance. We believe that there are unlimited use cases for this emerging tech, and as a result, we want to build a tool that enables anyone to mint an NFT quickly and cheaply with any uploaded media asset with custom metadata on the blockchain of their choice.
submissions.team_members: Charlie Curnin, Charles Pan, Allie Littleton, Adi Sidapara, Ankush Swarnakar

submissions.description: Five artisan soap-making small business owners from the United States were interviewed for their perspectives on soap ingredient sourcing challenges to identify general trends in the small business chemical supply chains. An analysis of price variation in ingredient markets was then used to validate their claims. A custom set of web scraping and browser automation tools were prototyped both to facilitate the collection of unstructured data for the analysis and to collect user feedback from demonstrations.
submissions.project_name: Information asymmetry in online soap ingredient markets and opportunities for improved efficiency in ecommerce
submissions.team_members: Russell Tran

submissions.description: We built a crows-sourced educational website which allows you to describe and organize different topics or fields (like Computer Science, Basketball, Math etc) in a tree-based hierarchy. It is like a cross between wikipedia and skillshare, meant to both help people understand what is out there and how to approach big fields and to find the appropriate tutorials for the skills needed as they progress through a field or subfield! Users can save trees, create trees and contribute to other trees.
submissions.team_members: Rhett Owen, Trisha Kulkarni, Frankie Cerkvenik

submissions.description: SALVIS is your one-stop shop for building your program and will make the process of choosing your courses fun and exciting. With friendly visuals and graphs to help you visualize and track progress, you no longer have to wonder about which requirements you may be missing.
submissions.project_name: SALVIS: Time to get rid of the excel sheet
submissions.team_members: Tristan Sinclair, Renasha Mishra. Yasmine Mitchell, Daulet Tuleubayev

submissions.description: Inspired by Amazon’s product review tagging and summarization features, I've worked on a proof-of-concept data product that we can potentially bring to the Carta platform as a new feature.  Given enough review data, I envision the empowered Carta user being able to filter reviews by server-generated key-phrases and their associated sentiments for each course offering.
submissions.project_name: Extracting Course Review Features & their Sentiments via Dependency Parsing
submissions.team_members: Kyle Orciuch

submissions.description: Bringing elegant UI for all your queue management needs. Removing student and TA frustrations from existing queue tools.
submissions.team_members: Matt Trost, Keegan Mehall, Sotiris Papasotiriou, Max Mark, Ryan Tran

submissions.description:
Kara aims to revolutionize the donation experience of people worldwide. 

Kara is designed as a social network that connects donors (mentors) with people in need of financial help (protégés). Protégés and mentors are matched based on their preferences and can form a personal relationship through private messaging and interaction via social feeds. Mentors can directly send money to their protégés, helping them achieve their basic needs. Once that need is met, mentors get notified via a picture, call or video, which allows them to directly see the impact of their donation. 

Kara aims to increase worldwide donations by providing an intuitive platform with mechanisms designed to incentivize donors to give more.
submissions.project_name: Kara : A social network to reduce the world's inequality
submissions.team_members: Houda Nait El Barj, Julio Ballista, Jhonatan Ewunetie, Neena Dolores Romero, Rayan Albraidi

submissions.description: A round-robin game in which users produce a poem together by each contributing one line at a time.
submissions.team_members: Diego Balvin, Jen Luo, Meilinda Sun

submissions.description: Our overarching goal is to explore the possibilities of camera mechanics in GHA and develop a camera feature that is engaging to users. Aside from the traditional expectations of a camera to take pictures and store them in an album, we also want to leverage the reality-defying aspect of VR by implementing features that allow users to collect and replicate artifacts using the camera. The test and implementation of these ‘non-traditional’ features will be realized through a museum-themed outer game loop where the player can curate a museum by visiting new sites, taking pictures and collecting artifacts.
submissions.team_members: Nina Du, Abla Ghaleb, Landis, Bhagirath Mehta, Mia Miao

submissions.description:
Fetch your love for adventure and put on an Oculus Quest 2 headset to embark on a 10-minute archaeology-themed experience at one of the wonders of the world, the prehistoric monument of Stonehenge. In this game, you are a graduate student searching for project inspiration under the guidance of your eccentric professor.
Explore the richly rendered environment, discover historical artifacts, and perhaps even converse with the storytelling spirits of the past. Do you have what it takes to craft your own theory about the mysteries of Stonehenge?
(This was made in collaboration with Meta’s Global Historical Archive.)
submissions.project_name: ARCH: A VR Stonehenge Storytelling Experience
submissions.team_members: Shana Hadi, Jonathan Kula, Lina Fang, Jiahui Chen

submissions.description: How can historical experiences in VR be more engaging and better support cultural learning? How do we provide replay value, ie. encourage users to return to explore other sites? How do we scale this process? Our project explores each of these questions, working with Meta’s Global Historical Archive (GHA). We present a personable VR prototype experience, including interactions with culturally relevant characters, and a scalable narrative framework to apply to future historical sites. We also present an immersive VR trivia experience, which solidifies user’s historical knowledge gained through the narrative experience.
submissions.project_name: Reimagining and Scaling Historical Storytelling in VR (GHA)
submissions.team_members: Gizem Incesu, Jessica Chen, Emily Redmond, Nicholas Vo

submissions.description: Today’s students are managing incredibly complex calendars, containing classes, meetings, meals, and assignments.  Blueprint is a calendar-based system that allows students to better manage their time by applying tools that have been used successfully in the project management industry, including kanban timelines, multi-source input, and deep analytics.  With Blueprint, students can manage their static (fixed starting and ending time) as well as continuous (fluid events such as assignments) seamlessly, and receive key insights that can help them better manage their time.  We provide options for students to connect their account with popular apps like Canvas and Outlook, allowing for quick onboarding and use.
submissions.team_members: Armaun Sanayei, Mac Klinkachorn, Maeghan Tovar, Robbie Selwyn

submissions.description:
Vahana is a phone app designed to help new drivers improve their driving in a fun and engaging way. Think Strava meets Spotify Wrapped for driving.

Vahana allows users to record their driving, and then analyses and rates their drives with a safety score. Vahana also provides monthly statistics on users' driving progress. By recording safety score trends and analytical data, Vahana hopes to enable users to become safer drivers.
submissions.team_members: Alex Fu, Catherine Huang, Julia Kadie, Nick Mayhew

submissions.description: The "cold start" or new user problem has long plagued recommender systems. In order to resolve this problem before a user churns, exploration mechanisms are applied to learn the user's preferences in as few interactions as possible. This project introduces a novel exploration mechanism based on determinantal point processes that results in more sample-efficient exploration. It also introduces a standardized testing pipeline for exploration mechanisms based on the MovieLens dataset and a baseline Deep Q-Learning model.
submissions.project_name: Applying Determinantal Point Processes for Sample-efficient Exploration in Recommender Systems
submissions.team_members: Dhruvik Parikh

submissions.description: Our project aims to create a space where undergraduates can compare schedules and share courses they are currently and are planning on taking. We want to be the social middle ground between Explore Courses and Carta, allowing users to clearly visualize what their and their peers' schedules will look like.
submissions.team_members: Grace Alwan, Dean Stratakos, Jiwon Lee, Melissa Daniels, Tara Jones

submissions.description:
Learning a new language is one of the most challenging tasks for people of all ages and backgrounds. Yet, language, since the beginning of human organization, is one of the most reliable bridges to other cultures in an interconnected world.

Translation-based apps such as Duolingo, fail to consider one of the most important metrics to language absorption speed and volume: immersion. 

Arla uses AR technology to address this immersion gap. By using familiar objects in the user’s environment through the phone camera, Arla links the user’s memory of the real world to new terms. This tool will help users build their vocabulary, anywhere they go, in an effective and enduring way.
submissions.project_name: Arla: Augmented Reality Language Learning iOS App
submissions.team_members: Aaron Schultz, Kimmy Chang, Laikh Tewari, Michelle Xing, Ryota Ray Eki

submissions.description: MethaneSAT is a satellite that will be launched in 2 years to track methane emissions from oil and gas facilities. However, we needed to build a dataset of the locations of the oil and gas facilities using satellite imagery.
submissions.team_members: Erfan Rostami

submissions.description:
To continually monitor decarbonization progress and track emissions in the electricity sector, new tools are needed. In particular, accurate forecasts of grid carbon emissions are essential to real time carbon accounting (for measuring carbon displacement) and a market associated with it. Using years of historical grid data in the US (electricity emissions, demand, generation by source, etc.), we develop models to forecast CO2 emissions from electricity demand and generation. Analyzing these models enables us to understand when predictions are the most difficult. In light of increased renewable energy generation, we also ask whether increased renewable generation is related to worse forecast performance.

This senior project was is sponsored by Prof. Chris Piech. Prof. Jacques de Chalendar and Prof. Inês Azevedo helped frame the research questions and provided guidance.
submissions.project_name: Forecasting CO2 emissions on a decarbonizing electrical grid
submissions.team_members: Peter Maldonado

submissions.description: Chia Card is a service which enables sponsors to gift chia (XCH) to various recipients. Regardless of whether recipients are Crypto/Chia veterans or fledglings, our service ensures they enjoy a seamless and open welcome to the Chia community.
submissions.team_members: Natasha Ong, Lydia Chan, Nathaniel Goenawan, Andy Khuu, Vincent Heng

submissions.description: Mariposa is a VR app designed to immerse users within the brilliant world of butterflies, with an emphasis on shader development to simulate the anisotropic iridescence of blue morpho butterflies caused by light interacting with rows of tree-like nanostructures on the scales of their wings.
submissions.project_name: Mariposa: Simulating an Interactive Butterfly Exhibit in VR
submissions.team_members: Kayla Severson

submissions.description: Rekt Bear is Yahoo! Finance for the modern investor. We provide rankings of meme stocks, most shorted stocks, and stocks most active on Fidelity; we also track finance celebrities like Jim Cramer, Cathie Wood, and our wonderful elected officials who definitely don't use insider information. In addition, we provide traditional financial information (market movers, graphs, news, P/E ratio and other statistics, etc.).
submissions.team_members: Will Ellsworth

submissions.description: Split seeks to revolutionize the way friends split bills. Our platform will serve as a tool where users will no longer need to make calculations themselves, but simply take a picture of the receipt and select other users to share the payment with. Users will no longer have to overpay for that one friend that orders too much. We strive to provide consumers with a nuanced approach to bill splitting amongst friends.
submissions.team_members: Robert Hu, Luis Alcaraz, Josh Shongwe, Karen Chen

submissions.description: Trippy is a mobile application that aims to alleviate the task of dispersing incurred expenses and encourage groups to set and meet spending goals. Trippy tracks and handles incurred expenses throughout the trip by prompting users if recent purchases are part of the group expense. Once joint expenses have been confirmed, the app calculates what each party of the transaction owes.
submissions.team_members: Anthony Perez, Carolyn Asante-Darte, Sihguat Torres, Delali Azamati, Hana Tadesse

submissions.description: A drawing is worth a thousand beats; Drawdio will generate them for ya! Go to https://tinyurl.com/194-drawdio and dump your thoughts into a sketch. Drawdio will translate your drawing into music 🎵
submissions.team_members: Akram Sbaih, Donte Leon Townes, Justice Tyler, Dominic DeMarco, Jonathan Victorino

submissions.description: Non-accidental trauma (NAT) includes diagnoses such as domestic violence, assault, poisoning, and abuse. In this project, we developed a transformer-based model that uses electronic health record data to predict future diagnosis of NAT. Our model outperforms XGBoost and current state-of-the-art deep learning methods. Key to its performance was the use of a pretraining task for last visit summarization as well as incorporation of demographic and procedural features.
submissions.project_name: Transformer for Non-Accidental Trauma Prediction from Electronic Health Records
submissions.team_members: David Huang, Prof. David Kim (advisor), Prof. Serena Yeung (advisor)

submissions.description: In recent years, significant strides in the machine learning (ML) for healthcare community have led to the integration of ML models into clinical workflows in a number of areas. AI-based decision support tools typically aim to do two things: improve patient outcomes and reduce provider cost and burden. We study real-world production data from a chest x-ray interpretation aid deployed in Vietnam hospitals and analyze cases of AI-clinician disagreement. Inspired by this real-world data, we hypothesize that while AI-clinician collaborative performance could be improved by directly enhancing the underlying model, other aspects of collaboration are ripe for innovation. In particular, when and how to present model output should be motivated by characteristics such as the expected quality of a given prediction and whether the clinician is expected to agree with it along with clinical significance of the pathology in question. We, therefore, present a novel framework for AI-supported diagnosis using these characteristics, which is expected to mitigate risks of misdiagnosis while simultaneously reducing clinician burden.
submissions.project_name: Efficient and Accurate Integration of Diagnostic Machine Learning Models into Radiology Reporting Workflows
submissions.team_members: Viswesh Krishna, Morgan Sanchez, Kyle Alford

submissions.description: Parea is the home base for caretakers of patients with Autism Spectrum Disorder.
submissions.team_members: Lyna Kim, Taylor Lallas, Griffin Tarpenning, Mehul Arora

submissions.description: DAHA? is a mobile app designed to shape the way Stanford students buy, rent, and sell their belongings on campus. Inspired by DAHA requests in dorm chats and the need for Stanford seniors to sell their belongings before graduation, our app allows users to make campus-wide DAHA requests to alert the community about in-demand items. With this community DAHA list, members can see which belongings can be sold quickly, and make corresponding DAWA posts. By understanding the demand side of the market, we hope to reduce product wastage and promote reuse of belongings.
submissions.team_members: Krishnan Nair, Stephanie Hu, Rick Robert, Derian Williams, Adonis Pugh

submissions.description: Analytics are crucial to baseball front offices, helping management measure the true impact of players and coaches improve player performance. For this project, we worked closely with the Los Angeles Dodgers to develop a mobile app and API using deep-learning to extract patterns in player positions that can be used to improve performance. Our app enables coaches and players at the professional and amateur levels to use our model on uploaded video clips of players to better understand players' movements and how they relate to play outcomes and success on the field.
submissions.team_members: Raaisa Moktader, Jack Andraka, Peter Chatain, Ryan Atkins, Griffin Miller

submissions.description:
The use of self-supervised learning (SSL) algorithms has been on the rise across the machine learning community. SSL helps models acquire useful information from unlabelled data and then use this information to perform downstream tasks. The common paradigm here is to ‘pretrain’ on a large general dataset and then ‘finetune’ on a more specialized, typically smaller dataset.
The Domain-Agnostic Benchmark for Self-Supervised Learning (DABS) was published in NeurIPS last year, and has served as a benchmark for self-supervised learning algorithms. Specifically, to perform well on DABS, an algorithm must be pretrained on six unlabeled datasets from different domains: natural images, text, speech recordings, medical imaging, multichannel sensor data and image-text pairs.
(Tamkin et al.)
Through this Senior Project, I implemented a system for fast and large scale training of self-supervised learning algorithms with DABS. Specifically, I designed and wrote a JAX codebase for DABS — enabling us to run baseline algorithms on Google Cloud Tensor Processing Units, or TPUs, and have an order of magnitude faster training times.
submissions.project_name: Domain-Agnostic Benchmark for Self-Supervised Learning - writing a JAX codebase
submissions.team_members: Shashank Rammoorthy

submissions.description: In many industry computer vision tasks, large, labeled datasets are hard to come by. Therefore, when it comes to training deep neural networks, they have a hard time learning meaningful representations from the dataset. One way to visualize these models is through calculation of "attention maps" that display which parts of the input were important in making the associated prediction. Attention maps can be calculated in different ways, and as a result, do not always agree with each other. This problem becomes exacerbated when the model is overfitting to a small dataset. As a result, the QIAI lab proposes an unsupervised learning objective to be used as a fine-tuning step, where we calculate attention maps with 2 different algorithms and enforce a similarity metric between them.
submissions.project_name: Enforcing Attention Map Consistency for Unsupervised Finetuning
submissions.team_members: Max Pike

submissions.description: “Margaret” is an interactive short story that takes the form of a text conversation between the reader and a chatbot. Through an alternative form of storytelling, this project aims to incorporate user interaction to explore character construction and development in fiction.
submissions.team_members: Lily Zhou

submissions.description:
In this project we aim to establish the relationship between the
construction of an acoustic guitar and the resulting frequency and
amplitude response. The forward modeling problem is to take as
input the physical material parameters and geometry of a guitar
and use FEM methods to perform modal analysis. This part involves
modeling the guitar meshing, elasticity coefficients for the wood,
and different boundary conditions. The inverse problem (the more
interesting case) is to take as input the a user defined “sound” and
find the best parameters for a guitar that would produce such a
sound
submissions.team_members: Samaksh Goyal, Mark Rau, Doug James

submissions.description: This work uses various machine learning techniques (neural nets, SVMs, decision trees, etc.) to augment flow size estimates made from count-min sketching.
submissions.project_name: Flow Size Estimation Using Count-Min Sketches and Machine Learning
submissions.team_members: Ishan Gaur

submissions.description: How can we ease the burden of natural language data labeling and design virtual assistants that can correct errors made in understanding user input? In this project, I prototype a tool to simplify the process of labeling new training data for dialogue systems, and I explore methods of correcting a virtual assistant’s mistakes when interacting with a user.
submissions.team_members: Nathan Marks

submissions.description: Heatscape is an interactive, geographical visualizer of world news. We aggregate all the geographical references in the news and display them as a heatmap. Hotter spots correspond to areas with high news density. Click on any spot to see a list of news in the area. Too many news articles? No problem! Select any subset of categories to filter the news you see.
submissions.team_members: Mateo Arbelaez. Abraham Oliver. Griffin Kardos. Tessa Lisanti

submissions.description: Universal self-supervised (SSL) algorithms hold promise for making machine learning accessible to a range of high-impact domains, such as protein biology, manufacturing, and genomics. We present DABS 2.0: a set of improved datasets, algorithms, and software systems for advancing research on universal SSL. We extend the recently-introduced DABS benchmark with the addition of five real-world scientific domains: protein biology, bacterial genomics, multispectral satellite imagery, semiconductor wafers, and particle physics, bringing the total number of domains in the benchmark to twelve. We also propose a new universal SSL algorithm, Capri, and a generalized version of masked autoencoding, apply both on all twelve domains---the most wide-ranging exploration of SSL yet. We find that multiple algorithms show gains across all domains, outperforming previous baselines. In addition, we find that the optimal masking fraction varies based on the domain, and linear evaluator performance is not correlated with finetuning accuracy. We also present and open source our codebase, DABS-Launcher, which enables pretraining and transfer runs across all domains in <36 hours using compute resources that are free for academic researchers.
submissions.project_name: DABS 2.0: Improved Datasets, Algorithms, and Software Systems for Universal Self-Supervision
submissions.team_members: Gaurab Banerjee

submissions.description: Learning from human feedback has been shown to be a useful approach in acquiring robot reward functions. However, expert feedback is often assumed to be drawn from an underlying unimodal reward function. This assumption does not always hold, including in settings where multiple experts provide data or when a single expert provides data for different tasks. We thus have to go beyond learning a unimodal reward and focus on learning a multimodal reward function. We formulate the multimodal reward learning as a mixture learning problem and develop a novel ranking-based learning approach, in which the experts are only required to rank a given set of trajectories. Furthermore, as access to interaction data is often expensive in robotics, we develop an active querying approach to accelerate the learning process. We conduct experiments and user studies using a multi-task variant of OpenAI's LunarLander and a real Fetch robot, where we collect data from multiple users with different preferences. The results suggest that our approach can efficiently learn multimodal reward functions, and improve data-efficiency over benchmark methods that we adapt to our learning problem.
submissions.team_members: Vivek Myers

submissions.description: Conventional machine learning is quite energy intensive. However, for some tasks, higher energy efficiency can be achieved using hardware that emulates the brain by encoding signals as sequences of spikes. Concepts for such hardware are generally inflexible, yielding fixed network topologies. We propose a synapse circuit that could enable a configurable network layer and characterize its robustness through system level simulation.
submissions.project_name: A Synapse Circuit for a Configurable Neuromorphic Neural Network Layer
submissions.team_members: Malick Sere (student), Professor Sara Achour (Project advisor)

submissions.description:
The use of self-supervised learning (SSL) algorithms has been on the rise across the machine learning community. SSL helps models acquire useful information from unlabelled data and then use this information to perform downstream tasks. The common paradigm here is to ‘pretrain’ on a large general dataset and then ‘finetune’ on a more specialized, typically smaller dataset.
The Domain-Agnostic Benchmark for Self-Supervised Learning (DABS) was published earlier this year, and has served as a benchmark for self-supervised learning algorithms. Specifically, to perform well on DABS, an algorithm must be pretrained on six unlabeled datasets from different domains: natural images, text, speech recordings, medical imaging, multichannel sensor data and image-text pairs. 
Through this Senior Project, I implemented a system for fast and large scale training of self-supervised learning algorithms with DABS. Specifically, I designed and wrote a JAX codebase for DABS — enabling us to run baseline algorithms on Google Cloud Tensor Processing Units, or TPUs, and have an order of magnitude faster training times.
submissions.project_name: Domain Agnostic Benchmark for Self-supervised learning
submissions.team_members: Shashank Rammoorthy

submissions.description: FocusList is an an improved to-do list website to help you focus. When you have work to do, FocusList blocks distracting websites like social media. You can also import to-do list items from Google Calendar and Gmail.
submissions.team_members: Evan Baldonado, Lan Jiang, Jasper McAvity

submissions.description: The Honest Protocol is an ecosystem for decentralized audits of digital assets on Ethereum. It allows for a decentralized, validated database in which NFTs are labeled with honesty/anti-scam-related traits. This is necessary in a world in which NFT scams are rampant, and users do not know which proejcts to trust. Our project included two main parts: the smart contracts (deployed on an Ethereum testnet) and an API to interpret the smart contracts.
submissions.team_members: Alexis Mack, Kaili Wang, Jeff Tsang, Ryan Tan

submissions.description: Let’s Ride is a rideshare platform for Stanford students to post and join carpools. Our goal is to increase accessibility and frequency of carpools within the Stanford community, thereby increasing the mobility of students to get off-campus in a more affordable and environmentally-friendly way.
submissions.team_members: Cathy Zhang, Kasey Luo, Julie Wang

submissions.description: Discover who's on your Wavelength. Each week, submit your favorite song and our matching algorithm will match you with someone else on campus who listened to a different, but similar song. Make a new friend and discover new music along the way!
submissions.team_members: Amy Zhang, Juyon Lee, Hanna Yip, Trinity Donohugh

submissions.description: AllSpice is your favorite recipe-sharing app, perfect for storing recipes, sharing your creations with your friends, and following along with your friends' cooking adventures!
submissions.team_members: Valexa Orelien, Shreya Ravi, Anne Lee, Ben Choi, Isabelle Lee

submissions.description: We want to create a platform that will facilitate and encourage people to create and join advocacy groups. Our platform will allow people to plan and sign up for events and for people to receive notifications from causes they are following. Each person will have a home page of the causes they follow. The platform will also allow people to sign up for specific tasks to support an event.
submissions.team_members: Huong Nguyen, Drew Wadsworth, Abi Lopez, Xuchen Wei

submissions.description: Collide helps you break social barriers. By notifying you when people with shared interests are nearby, this mobile app creates opportunities to meet people you would have otherwise passed by. With Collide, your next best friend is just around the corner!
submissions.team_members: Ekin Tiu, Enok Choe, Emily Hsu, Christian Figueroa

submissions.description: Have you ever been looking to hit a concert, hike, or day trip, but your friends aren't available or you want to go with new people? DayTripper can be your means to connect with fellow college students and organize an incredible day.
submissions.team_members: Jasper Den Otter, David Malinak, Emmanuel Ayumba, Tyler Eischens

submissions.description: Carpe is an app built to facilitate community based carpooling.
submissions.team_members: Nebyou Zewde , Rafael Esteves, Ayush Agarwal

submissions.description: The Illusion architecture is designed to run deep learning workloads with total energy and execution time near that of an ideal single chip. The scaleup project aims to demonstrate that the architecture can keep pace with growing neural network sizes while maintaining its low overheads. Ongoing verification of a new chip that will demonstrate scaleup involves emulating the design in hardware to accelerate logic simulations. Emulation will allow the development team to test scaling the system before fabricating the design.
submissions.project_name: Emulating Illusion Scaleup for Neural Network Applications​
submissions.team_members: Ben Auslin

submissions.description:
Almost everyone has considered joining a startup at one point in their career. However, the process is incredibly annoying. You have to:

go through job boards with thousands of company names you’ve never heard of
vet each startup’s funding + product + team background
then make sure your profile fits the exact tech stack that the startup is looking for
finally spend hours writing an application that will never get read
all the while you’re working a full-time job at your current company

We've almost entirely automated the job search process to be handled mostly over email, at scale. Given a shortlist of preferences, each user will be given the best matches that exactly match their skills and interests, with an 'easy-to-vet' process. These matches then directly lead to interviews and phone screens!
submissions.team_members: Bryce Hunt, Raymond Guo, David Witten, Roy Yuan

submissions.description: Today’s students are managing incredibly complex calendars, containing classes, meetings, meals, and assignments.  Blueprint is a calendar-based system that allows students to better manage their time by applying tools that have been used successfully in the project management industry, including kanban timelines, multi-source input, and deep analytics.  With Blueprint, students can manage their static (fixed starting and ending time) as well as continuous (fluid events such as assignments) seamlessly, and receive key insights that can help them better manage their time.  We provide options for students to connect their account with popular apps like Canvas and Outlook, allowing for quick onboarding and use.
submissions.team_members: Armaun Sanayei , Robbie Selwyn, Maeghan Tovar, Mac Klinkachorn

submissions.description: Procedurally Generated Video Game Tilemaps from a Drawing
submissions.team_members: Cole Sohn

submissions.description: This project is a study of using Dueling Double Deep Q-Networks with different network architectures to train an autonomous vehicle in a custom simulation environment in Unreal4 combining Carla and Airsim.
submissions.project_name: Training an Autonomous Vehicle in Simulation with Dueling Double Deep Q-Networks
submissions.team_members: Rita Tlemcani

submissions.description: A rogue-like shooter with creature collection elements
submissions.team_members: Jordan Walker, Kevin Su, Eli Vazquez, Michael Vernau, Kaitlin Hsu

submissions.description: Floor 47 is a VR gardening-experience developed in CS11SI. Our team worked to develop a relaxing, immersive gardening application using hand tracking focused features to navigate, design, and tend to your own personal garden.
submissions.team_members: Vencent Vang, Jasmine Sumpter, Steven Le, Emmanuel Angel Corona

submissions.description: Potecha offers a one stop shop for all ceremonial items from trusted community vendors. Unlike Facebook Marketplace, Potecha will target members of indiginous communites and provide a tailored experience to help community members find authentic clothing and items.
submissions.team_members: Jorge Martinez Alba, Pilli Cruz de Jesus, Grant Sheen, Nick Walker

submissions.description: Arla is a language learning app for iOS that uses augmented reality to help students learn vocabulary based on the objects in their everyday environment. The app allows students to translate an object simply by pointing their phone camera at it. Additional features include saving photos as flashcards and pronunciation help and testing.
submissions.team_members: Aaron Schultz, Laikh Tewari, Kimmy Chang, Michelle Xing, Ryota Eki
